L1: # Agent Task
L2: 
L3: Task id: gcse-chemistry-8-9
L4: Task title: GCSE chemistry grade 8-9 multi-step quantitative solving
L5: Reference paper: GCSE Chemistry topic set (AQA specification-aligned, synthesized benchmark)
L6: Reference URL: https://www.aqa.org.uk/subjects/science/gcse/chemistry-8462/specification-at-a-glance
L7: 
L8: ## Objective
L9: Read the report and produce all required JSON outputs that satisfy their schemas.
L10: 
L11: ## Inputs On Disk
L12: - Report: `input/report.md`
L13: - Schemas: in `schemas/`
L14: 
L15: ## Required Outputs
L16: - `output/problem_01.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_01.schema.json`)
L17: - `output/problem_02.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_02.schema.json`)
L18: - `output/problem_03.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_03.schema.json`)
L19: - `output/problem_04.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_04.schema.json`)
L20: - `output/problem_05.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_05.schema.json`)
L21: - `output/problem_06.json` (schema: `schemas/problem_06.schema.json`)
L22: 
L23: ## Constraints
L24: - Do not invent source facts; derive calculations only from values in the report.
L25: - Use line refs as `L<number>` where required.
L26: - Where quotes are required, copy exact report snippets.
L27: - For calculation outputs, line_refs must include every report line used for equations, constants, and numeric substitutions.
L28: - Use relative paths only.
L29: - Never use absolute paths.
L30: - Never use `..` in paths.
L31: - Write valid JSON only.
L32: 
L33: ## Completion
L34: Respond with a checklist of written output files.

L1: # GCSE Chemistry Quantitative Challenge (Grade 8-9)
L2: 
L3: ## Provenance
L4: - Scope: GCSE Chemistry Higher Tier style quantitative problem set.
L5: - Benchmark note: This is a synthesized exam-style set aligned with AQA GCSE Chemistry (8462) quantitative topics.
L6: - Specification reference: https://www.aqa.org.uk/subjects/science/gcse/chemistry-8462/specification-at-a-glance
L7: 
L8: ## Instructions
L9: - Solve each problem from the given data only.
L10: - Use appropriate significant figures and clear working.
L11: - Use only equations/constants listed in this document.
L12: 
L13: ## Constants and Formula Reminders
L14: - Moles: n = m / Mr
L15: - Concentration: c = n / V (V in dm3)
L16: - Dilution: c1V1 = c2V2
L17: - Charge: Q = I * t
L18: - Moles of electrons: n(e-) = Q / F
L19: - Faraday constant: F = 96,500 C mol-1
L20: - At equilibrium for N2O4(g) <-> 2NO2(g): Kc = [NO2]^2 / [N2O4]
L21: - Report Kc as dimensionless (unitless).
L22: 
L23: ## Atomic / Formula Data
L24: - H = 1.0, C = 12.0, O = 16.0, S = 32.1, Ca = 40.1, Cu = 63.55
L25: - Mr(CaCO3) = 100.1
L26: - Mr(CO2) = 44.0
L27: 
L28: ## Problem P01 (Dilution)
L29: A technician transfers 25.0 cm3 of 0.200 mol dm-3 HCl into a volumetric flask and dilutes it with water to a final volume of 250.0 cm3.
L30: Find the new concentration of HCl in mol dm-3.
L31: 
L32: ## Problem P02 (Stoichiometry + Purity)
L33: Limestone sample mass = 5.00 g. The sample is 84.0% CaCO3 by mass.
L34: Reaction: CaCO3 + 2HCl -> CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O
L35: Assume acid is in excess.
L36: Calculate the maximum mass of CO2 that can be produced.
L37: 
L38: ## Problem P03 (Titration)
L39: 25.00 cm3 of H2SO4 is neutralized by 23.40 cm3 of 0.150 mol dm-3 NaOH.
L40: Reaction: H2SO4 + 2NaOH -> Na2SO4 + 2H2O
L41: Calculate the concentration of H2SO4 in mol dm-3.
L42: 
L43: ## Problem P04 (Bond Energy Estimate)
L44: Estimate deltaH for methane combustion using mean bond energies.
L45: Equation: CH4 + 2O2 -> CO2 + 2H2O
L46: Bond energies (kJ mol-1): C-H = 413, O=O = 498, C=O (in CO2) = 805, O-H = 463
L47: Use: deltaH = sum(bonds broken) - sum(bonds formed)
L48: 
L49: ## Problem P05 (Electrolysis)
L50: Copper is deposited during electrolysis of aqueous CuSO4 using inert electrodes.
L51: Current = 1.50 A, time = 30.0 min.
L52: Half-equation at cathode: Cu2+ + 2e- -> Cu
L53: Calculate the mass of copper deposited.
L54: 
L55: ## Problem P06 (Equilibrium Constant)
L56: For N2O4(g) <-> 2NO2(g), at equilibrium in a 2.00 dm3 vessel:
L57: - moles(NO2) = 0.180 mol
L58: - moles(N2O4) = 0.220 mol
L59: Calculate Kc.

problem_01.json
problem_02.json
problem_03.json
problem_04.json
problem_05.json
problem_06.json

Mass of CO2 = n×Mr = 0.04196×44.0 = 1.846 g, which rounds to 1.85 g.\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"n = m/Mr\\\",\\n    \\\"m = n×Mr\\\",\\n    \\\"CaCO3 : CO2 = 1 : 1 (from the balanced equation)\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L14\\\",\\n    \\\"L24\\\",\\n    \\\"L33\\\",\\n    \\\"L34\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"If the sample were 100% CaCO3, CO2 mass would be 5.00×(44.0/100.1) ≈ 2.20 g; at 84.0% purity, expect ≈ 1.85 g, consistent.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",

Convert the acid volume: 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3. Concentration of H2SO4 = n/V = 0.001755/0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"c = n/V\\\",\\n    \\\"n = cV\\\",\\n    \\\"H2SO4 : NaOH = 1 : 2 (from the balanced equation)\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L15\\\",\\n    \\\"L39\\\",\\n    \\\"L40\\\",\\n    \\\"L41\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Moles NaOH is about 3.5×10^-3; halving gives ~1.75×10^-3 mol acid in 0.025 dm3, so c should be ~0.07 mol dm-3.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",

  "arguments": "{\"file_path\":\"output/problem_04.json\",\"content\":\"{\\n  \\\"problem_id\\\": \\\"P04\\\",\\n  \\\"final_answer\\\": {\\n    \\\"value\\\": -814,\\n    \\\"units\\\": \\\"kJ mol-1\\\",\\n    \\\"precision_note\\\": \\\"Rounded to the nearest kJ mol-1; mean bond energies are given as whole-number estimates.\\\"\\n  },\\n  \\\"method\\\": \\\"Use ΔH = Σ(bonds broken) − Σ(bonds formed). For CH4 + 2O2 → CO2 + 2H2O: bonds broken are 4×(C–H) from CH4 and 2×(O=O) from 2O2. So Σbroken = 4×413 + 2×498 = 1652 + 996 = 2648 kJ mol-1. Bonds formed are 2×(C=O) in CO2 and 4×(O–H) in 2H2O (each H2O has 2 O–H bonds). So Σformed = 2×805 + 4×463 = 1610 + 1852 = 3462 kJ mol-1. Therefore ΔH = 2648 − 3462 = −814 kJ mol-1 (exothermic).\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"ΔH = Σ(bonds broken) − Σ(bonds formed)\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L45\\\",\\n    \\\"L46\\\",\\n    \\\"L47\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Combustion reactions are expected to be exothermic, so a negative ΔH is sensible.\\\",\\n    \\\"Magnitude is hundreds of kJ mol-1, consistent with typical combustion enthalpies estimated by bond energies.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",

Charge passed Q = I×t = 1.50×1800 = 2700 C. Faraday constant gives charge per mole of electrons, so moles of electrons n(e−) = Q/F = 2700/96500 = 0.02798 mol. From Cu2+ + 2e− → Cu, 2 mol e− deposit 1 mol Cu, so n(Cu) = 0.02798/2 = 0.01399 mol. Using the molar mass of copper from the atomic data (63.55 g mol−1), mass Cu = 0.01399×63.55 = 0.8886 g, which rounds to 0.889 g.\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"Q = It\\\",\\n    \\\"n(e−) = Q/F\\\",\\n    \\\"n(Cu) = n(e−)/2\\\",\\n    \\\"m = n×Mr\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L19\\\",\\n    \\\"L24\\\",\\n    \\\"L51\\\",\\n    \\\"L52\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"2700 C corresponds to about 0.028 mol e−; half of that is ~0.014 mol Cu, giving ~0.014×64 ≈ 0.9 g, consistent.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",
  "call_id": "call_IjDWcW9aDQQzP9TtoqTbJlqC",
  "name": "write_file",

Convert moles to concentrations using the 2.00 dm3 vessel: [NO2] = 0.180/2.00 = 0.0900 mol dm−3 and [N2O4] = 0.220/2.00 = 0.110 mol dm−3. Substitute: Kc = (0.0900)^2/0.110 = 0.00810/0.110 = 0.073636…, so Kc = 0.0736 (dimensionless).\\\",\\n  \\\"key_equations\\\": [\\n    \\\"Kc = [NO2]^2/[N2O4]\\\",\\n    \\\"[species] = n/V\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"line_refs\\\": [\\n    \\\"L20\\\",\\n    \\\"L56\\\",\\n    \\\"L57\\\",\\n    \\\"L58\\\"\\n  ],\\n  \\\"checks\\\": [\\n    \\\"Because NO2 is less concentrated than N2O4 here, Kc should be less than 1; 0.0736 matches that expectation.\\\",\\n    \\\"Recomputing via moles: Kc = (nNO2^2)/(nN2O4×V) = (0.180^2)/(0.220×2.00) ≈ 0.0736, consistent.\\\"\\n  ]\\n}\\n\"}",
  "call_id": "call_EW6g53fESXdvSMAnfJhbb5iH",
  "name": "write_file",
  "parsed_arguments": null
}\n

input.content:
{
  "problem_id": "P05",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.889,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "3 s.f., limited by 1.50 A, 30.0 min, and F = 96,500 C mol-1 (all 3 s.f.)."
  },
  "method": "Convert time to seconds: 30.0 min × 60 = 1800 s. Charge passed Q = I×t = 1.50×1800 = 2700 C. Faraday constant gives charge per mole of electrons, so moles of electrons n(e−) = Q/F = 2700/96500 = 0.02798 mol. From Cu2+ + 2e− → Cu, 2 mol e− deposit 1 mol Cu, so n(Cu) = 0.02798/2 = 0.01399 mol. Using the molar mass of copper from the atomic data (63.55 g mol−1), mass Cu = 0.01399×63.55 = 0.8886 g, which rounds to 0.889 g.",
  "key_equations": [
    "Q = It",
    "n(e−) = Q/F",
    "n(Cu) = n(e−)/2",
    "m = n×Mr"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L19",
    "L24",
    "L51",
    "L52"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "2700 C corresponds to about 0.028 mol e−; half of that is ~0.014 mol Cu, giving ~0.014×64 ≈ 0.9 g, consistent."
  ]
}
